thread.title: 7 things to know about today, plus taxpayer cyberattacks worse than thought
thread.title_full: 7 things to know about today, plus taxpayer cyberattacks worse than thought

author: Cindy Barth
title: 7 things to know about today, plus taxpayer cyberattacks worse than thought
text: ThinkStock The Internal Revenue Service says identity thieves may have attacked thousands more… more The Internal Revenue Service says identity thieves may have attacked thousands more taxpayer accounts than the agency thought when a review was done in May. The IRS said in May it had determined “unauthorized third parties” used the agency’s "Get Transcript" application to gain access to 114,000 accounts. In addition, hackers made another 111,000 attempts that failed to pass the final verification step needed to gain information. The IRS said Monday a new review identified an additional 220,000 attempts where individuals “with taxpayer-specific sensitive data” cleared the Get Transcript verification process, meaning hackers accessed information. The review also identified an additional 170,000 suspected attempts that failed to clear the authentication processes. The IRS said it will, as it did in May, mail letters to taxpayers who may have been affected by hackers’ attempts to gain access to the IRS system. The IRS will also offer free credit protection as well as Identity Protection PINs. The “Get Transcript” application was shut down in May, the IRS said. And be sure to check out these other Tuesday headlines: SeaWorld names new CFO, chief creative officer Orlando-based SeaWorld Entertainment Inc. (NYSE: SEAS) appointed Peter J. Crage to serve as chief financial officer, effective Sept. 1. Crage most recently served as CFO at Extended Stay America Inc. In addition, Anthony Esparza was named chief creative officer. Esparza previously served as senior vice president of guest experiences, design and development for Herschend Enterprises, the same company new SeaWorld CEO Joel Manby came from. "Peter and Anthony are strong and important additions to our leadership team as we continue to drive improvement in the company's performance, competitive position and shareholder value," said Manby. Read more here . Florida House makes moves to approve new congressional map After rejecting a proposal by Sarasota County lawmakers, the Florida House appears poised Tuesday to approve a congressional redistricting plan that seeks to align with an order from the state Supreme Court. House members Monday raised questions about a "base map" developed by staff members and attorneys but did not make any changes, setting the stage for approval Tuesday. The House and Senate, however, could pass different maps, forcing them to try to reach agreement on a final version before a special legislative session ends Friday. Read more here . Blue Bell sets date to return products to select markets Blue Bell Creameries will begin re-distributing its ice cream products on Aug. 31, but Floridians will have to wait a little longer for a scoop. The company is manufacturing the ice cream for its comeback in one facility in Sylacauga, Ala. Production remains halted at its facilities in Brenham, Texas, and Broken Arrow, Okla. Due to the limited production capacity, products will roll out to select markets in five phases, with the first phase set to begin at the end of August. Florida won't see the ice cream products until Phase 5. Blue Bell hasn't set any dates for the rollout beyond Phase 1. Read more here . Will Wells Fargo land in hot water over voracious appetite for its own shares? Wells Fargo has invested billions over the years in repurchasing its own shares, even as buybacks gain unfavorable attention from politicians but remain popular with many investors. From an investor's perspective, share buybacks can contribute to rising earnings-per-share and stock prices as ownership of a company is represented by fewer shares. Now, some politicians are criticizing stock buybacks as stock manipulation and questioning why banks aren't, instead, using the money to expand, lend and create jobs. Click here to read more from the San Francisco Business Times. Wells Fargo is the third-largest bank by deposit market share in Central Florida, with 56 offices and $6.98 billion in deposits.
